title: Authors and Citation
text: Palle D (2025). sparseNumeric: Sparse Numeric Vector Class Methods. R package version 0.1.0, https://github.com/druthipalle/sparseNumeric.
code: @Manual{,   title = {sparseNumeric: Sparse Numeric Vector Class and Methods},   author = {Druthi Palle},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 0.1.0},   url = {https://github.com/druthipalle/sparseNumeric}, }

what: Sparse Numeric Vector Class and Methods
title: Sparse Numeric Vector Class and Methods
text: goal sparseNumeric provide class sparse numeric vectors set methods work without ever converting dense vector. sparse_numeric object stores: - value: non-zero entries - pos: positions - length: full length underlying vector package implements arithmetic, summary, utility methods : - sparse_add(), sparse_sub(), sparse_mult(), sparse_crossprod() - sum(), mean(), norm(), standardize() - plot() show() methods visualization printing

title: Sparse Numeric Vector Class and Methods
text: can install development version sparseNumeric like :
code: # install.packages("devtools")   # if needed devtools::install_github("druthipalle/sparseNumeric") #> Using GitHub PAT from the git credential store. #> Downloading GitHub repo druthipalle/sparseNumeric@HEAD #> ── R CMD build ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #>      checking for file ‘/private/var/folders/c_/zwvmhty113b4mqm71k50xd100000gn/T/RtmpedPWHf/remotesd53376de54bd/druthipalle-sparseNumeric-f2b40e9/DESCRIPTION’ ...  ✔  checking for file ‘/private/var/folders/c_/zwvmhty113b4mqm71k50xd100000gn/T/RtmpedPWHf/remotesd53376de54bd/druthipalle-sparseNumeric-f2b40e9/DESCRIPTION’ #>   ─  preparing ‘sparseNumeric’: #>      checking DESCRIPTION meta-information ...  ✔  checking DESCRIPTION meta-information #>   ─  checking for LF line-endings in source and make files and shell scripts #>   ─  checking for empty or unneeded directories #>      Omitted ‘LazyData’ from DESCRIPTION #>   ─  building ‘sparseNumeric_0.1.0.tar.gz’ #>       #>

title: Sparse Numeric Vector Class and Methods
text: basic example shows solve common problem:
code: library(sparseNumeric) #>  #> Attaching package: 'sparseNumeric' #> The following object is masked from 'package:base': #>  #>     norm  ## create a dense vector x_dense <- c(0,0,3,0,5)  ## convert to spare_numeric x_sp <- sparse_numeric(x_dense) x_sp #> sparse_numeric vector of length 5  #>  pos value #>    3     3 #>    5     5  ## length length(x_sp) #> [1] 5  ## sum and mean sum(x_sp) #> [1] 8 mean(x_sp) #> [1] 1.6  ## euclidean norm norm(x_sp) #> [1] 5.830952  ## standardize x_std <- standardize(x_sp) x_std #> [1] -0.6949956 -0.6949956  0.6081211 -0.6949956  1.4768656  mean(x_std)  # should be ~0 #> [1] -8.881784e-17 sd(x_std)    # should be ~1 #> [1] 1 ## arithmetic and dot product  y_dense <- c(1,0,0,2,0) y_sp <- sparse_numeric(y_dense)  ## elementwise operations sparse_add(x_sp, y_sp) #> sparse_numeric vector of length 5  #>  pos value #>    1     1 #>    3     3 #>    4     2 #>    5     5 sparse_sub(x_sp, y_sp) #> sparse_numeric vector of length 5  #>  pos value #>    1    -1 #>    3     3 #>    4    -2 #>    5     5 sparse_mult(x_sp, y_sp) #> sparse_numeric vector of length 5  #>   (all elements are zero)  ## dot product sparse_crossprod(x_sp, y_sp) #> [1] 0 plot(x_sp, y_sp)

title: Mean of a sparse_numeric vector — mean,sparse_numeric-method

what: Euclidean norm of a sparse_numeric vector — norm
title: Euclidean norm of a sparse_numeric vector — norm
text: Computes Euclidean (L2) norm, .e. \(sqrt(sum(x_i^2))\).

what: Sparse numeric vector S4 class — sparse_numeric-class
title: Sparse numeric vector S4 class — sparse_numeric-class
text: Represents sparse numeric vector, storing non-zero values positions along full vector length.

title: Sparse numeric vector S4 class — sparse_numeric-class
text: value Numeric vector non-zero values. pos Integer vector positions non-zero values (1-based, sorted, unique). length Single non-negative integer giving full length.

title: Standardize a sparse_numeric vector — standardize
text: Standardizes full vector (including zeros) mean 0 standard deviation 1. Since almost standardized elements typically non-zero, method returns dense numeric vector.
